title: Men Tied to Violent White-Supremacist Group Plead Guilty to Firearms Charges
sub_head: Prosecutors say two men were members of group that seeks to overthrow U.S. government
body:
Two men prosecutors say are affiliated with the Base, a violent white-supremacist group that seeks to overthrow the U.S. government, pleaded guilty in a Maryland courtroom on Thursday to firearms, obstruction of justice and other federal charges.
The men intended to sow chaos at a January 2020 pro-gun rally in Richmond, Va., prosecutors said in an earlier court filing, and had discussed ambushing and killing a police officer and tossing firecrackers into a crowd there. The men also contemplated attempts to sabotage power lines, derail trains and poison water supplies to bring on economic collapse, prosecutors said.
Charges against Brian Mark Lemley Jr., a 35-year-old U.S. Army veteran, include transporting a machine gun and helping the other defendant, Patrik Jordan Mathews, 28, a former Canadian Army reservist, enter the U.S. illegally and obtain a firearm. Both men were also charged with obstruction of justice, with prosecutors saying they destroyed their cellphones and dumped them in a toilet in an effort to thwart an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Authorities said Mr. Mathews entered the U.S. illegally after he was identified in 2019 by the Winnipeg Free Press as a member of the Base. A reporter for the newspaper had conducted an undercover investigation of the group, prompting a law-enforcement probe in Canada.
Prosecutors said the Base seeks out members with military and explosives backgrounds. In detailing the firearms charges, prosecutors said Messrs. Mathews and Lemley constructed a rifle and trained at gun ranges in Maryland and Georgia.
